channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia-Ukraine War: Kremlin Denies Involvement in Crash Presumed to Have Killed Mercenary Leader
item.description: U.S. officials appeared increasingly certain that Yevgeny V. Prigozhin was dead and that President Vladimir V. Putin had ordered his killing. The Kremlin has previously denied actions it was later shown to have carried out.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A ceremony for Ukraine’s Independence Day, in Kyiv, on Thursday.

item.title: Yevgeny Prigozhin, Renegade Mercenary Chief Who Rattled Kremlin
item.description: A tycoon and a Putin ally, he built a paramilitary force that fought by Russia’s side even as he castigated its military leaders. He is believed dead at 62 in a plane crash.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: A screengrab from a video provided by Concord Press Service, Mr. Prigozhin’s information agency, showing him at a cemetery for Wagner fighters in Russia’s southern Krasnodar region in April.

item.title: BRICS Group Announces New Members, Including Iran and Saudi Arabia
item.description: Argentina, Ethiopia and the U.A.E. were also invited to join BRICS, strengthening the group’s role as an alternative to Western-led forums.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger, David Pierson and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Representing the BRICS nations in Johannesburg were, from left, President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil, President Xi Jinping of China, President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and Sergey V. Lavrov, the foreign minister of Russia.

item.title: BRICS Invites More Countries to Join. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Iran was the surprise among the countries invited to join the bloc of emerging economies. Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Egypt, Argentina and Ethiopia were also tapped.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Vivian Yee, Natalie Alcoba and Declan Walsh
item.media:description: From left, President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil, President Xi Jinping of China, President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia at the BRICS conference in Johannesburg on Thursday.

item.title: Zimbabwe’s Ballot Delays Force Election Into 2nd Day
item.description: Other voters in Zimbabwe had to return the next day to vote for president, and the police raided election observers. The main candidates both predicted victory.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.category: Citizens Coalition for Change (Zimbabwean Political Party)
item.media:description: A polling station in Harare, Zimbabwe, on Thursday. Most of the voting problems were in urban areas, where the opposition tends to be stronger.

item.title: Prigozhin Broke the First Rule in Russia: Don’t Defy Putin
item.description: The fate of Yevgeny V. Prigozhin is a reminder of all those who have paid a heavy price for standing up to President Vladimir V. Putin, and of how quickly people can fall from his favor.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:credit: Gavriil Grigorov/Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media showing President Vladimir V. Putin addressing the nation on June 26.

item.title: As Wildfires Spread, Anger Rises in Greece Over Government Response
item.description: Firefighters were battling scores of blazes nationwide, but the threat to a precious woodland north of the capital had some fearing a dystopian future.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Flames rising above Mount Parnitha in Athens early Thursday morning.

item.title: India’s Moon Landing Offers Blueprint For Other Countries Dreaming Big
item.description: Its celebrated lunar landing produced not only a wave of pride at home but also a road map for other countries.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: Celebrating India’s lunar landing in Srinagar on Wednesday. The country’s tradition of scientific and technological excellence offers a blueprint to other nations.

item.title: ‘Aren’t You a Man?’: How Russia Goads Citizens Into the Army
item.description: The Times tracked several months of Russian state messaging in the Kremlin’s effort to recruit soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Alina Lobzina, Sarah Kerr and Natalie Reneau

item.title: Thailand’s Old Guard Keeps Its Grip After Voters Seek Change
item.description: The country went months without naming a new prime minister, only for Parliament to elect Srettha Thavisin, a candidate who many frustrated voters say represents the establishment.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Pita Limjaroenrat, the Move Forward Party leader, center with microphone, at a rally in Pattaya, Thailand, last month.

item.title: Japan Starts Releasing Radioactive Fukushima Water
item.description: China said it would suspend imports of Japanese seafood in response to what it has called an unsafe plan to dispose of the wastewater.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: The Fukushima Daichi nuclear power plant on Thursday.

item.title: King Charles to Visit France in September, After Protests Forced Delay
item.description: The British monarch was supposed to make the trip in March, but widespread demonstrations over a change in the French retirement age scuttled the plan.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III’s plans for an early state visit were a signal of warming relations between Britain and France.

item.title: What to Know About Zimbabwe’s Presidential Election
item.description: The country needs a free and fair election to escape Western sanctions. But voting got off to a rough start, with late openings at polling places and fliers spreading misinformation.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Moyo, Tendai Marima and John Eligon
item.category: Citizens Coalition for Change (Zimbabwean Political Party)
item.media:description: Registering to vote at a polling station in Mbare, Zimbabwe, a suburb of the capital Harare, on Wednesday. Voters encountered frustrating delays as voting began.

item.title: A Late Summer Heat Wave Bakes Italy, France and Spain
item.description: In France, Spain and Italy, residents and tourists did their best to avoid scorching temperatures — again.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chaundler and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Residents trying to reach their houses over the weekend as a wildfire advanced in La Orotava on Tenerife, in the Canary Islands.

item.title: Spanish Soccer Chief Rubiales Refuses to Resign Over World Cup Kiss
item.description: Luis Rubiales was denounced for his behavior toward Jennifer Hermoso, a member of the winning Spanish women’s soccer team, at an awards ceremony in Australia.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chaundler
item.media:description: Luis Rubiales, the president of the Royal Spanish Football Federation, hugging the Spanish forward Jennifer Hermoso after the Women’s World Cup final in Sydney, Australia, on Sunday.

item.title: Presumed Death of Wagner Leader Puts In Doubt Group’s Future in Africa
item.description: Since Yevgeny Prigozhin’s brief mutiny in June, the Kremlin has tried to assure African clients that it was in control. But analysts suggested that without its leader, Wagner’s future was uncertain.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wagner mercenaries guarding the president and other high-ranking attendees at a Labor Day event in Bangui, capital of the Central African Republic, in 2019.

item.title: Russia says Ukraine targeted Crimea with dozens of drones overnight.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

item.title: London Zoo Weighs Its Animals. All 14,000 of Them.
item.description: It can’t be easy to weigh a meerkat, but boy, does it look like fun.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Frank the Meerkat taking his turn on the scale.

item.title: Two Arrested After Crooked House Pub Fire
item.description: The Crooked House pub in England’s West Midlands went up in flames earlier this month. Two men have now been taken into custody on suspicion of arson.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Jacob King/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The burned-out remains of the Crooked House pub near Dudley, England.

item.title: Seafood Is Safe After Fukushima Discharge, But Some Won’t Eat It
item.description: Sushi is among several shunned foods as Japan dumps treated radioactive water into the Pacific. Experts say the fear is irrational but understandable.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives, John Yoon, Hisako Ueno and Olivia Wang
item.media:description: Vendors and customers at a wholesale fish market in Beijing on Thursday, when China banned all Japanese seafood imports.

item.title: Jair Candor Tracks Brazil’s Amazon Tribes From the Shadows
item.description: Jair Candor combs the forest for Indigenous people who want no contact with outsiders. The goal: to prove they exist so their land can be legally protected.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jair Candor is perhaps the most accomplished tracer of isolated tribes in Brazil. “My curiosity is great,” he said. “But the respect for their rights is greater.”

item.title: The 1,300-Year Search for the Loch Ness Monster: A Timeline
item.description: An expedition to find the creature will take place this weekend in Scotland. Here’s a look at previous attempts.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: Loch Ness in the 1960s. The biography of an Irish saint who visited Scotland in the sixth century includes the first known reference to the Loch Ness monster.

item.title: Friday Briefing: U.S. Believes Prigozhin Was Killed
item.description: Also, the tiny forests with big benefits.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Portraits of Russian mercenary chief Yevgeny Prigozhin and Wagner group commander Dmitry Utkin at a memorial outside the local office of the Wagner private mercenary group in Novosibirsk, Russia.

item.title: U.S. Says It Will Take Time to Confirm Prigozhin Was Killed in Plane Crash
item.description: The Wagner Group has not confirmed its leader’s death, nor has the Russian government.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.media:description: Debris from a plane that crashed in the Tver region of Russia on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine Says It Staged a Brief Raid in Occupied Crimea
item.description: Taking back the peninsula, which was annexed by Russia in 2014, has remained a core part of the Ukrainian war effort.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

item.title: Explosion Likely Downed Plane and Killed Prigozhin, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: The officials stressed that multiple theories about what brought down a plane in Russia were still being explored. President Putin acknowledged the incident and spoke about Yevgeny Prigozhin in the past tense.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt, Riley Mellen, Muyi Xiao and Robin Stein
item.media:description: Part of a crashed private jet near the village of Kuzhenkino, Russia, on Thursday.

item.title: Pentagon Plans to Begin Training Ukrainian Pilots on F-16s in U.S.
item.description: The decision is a shift from last week, when a U.S. official said the pilots could be trained in the United States if European training programs reached capacity.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Lara Jakes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Fadel Senna/Agency French Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A U.S. Air Force mechanic working on an F-16 fighter jet in 2021. The Pentagon will begin training Ukrainian pilots on the planes in the United States as early as next month, according to a U.S. official.

item.title: When Sea Ice Retreated, Some Emperor Penguins Didn’t Breed
item.description: New research indicates that a majority of emperor penguins in a region of Antarctica lost their chicks.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:description: Emperor penguins brooding on Snow Hill Island in Antarctica.

item.title: Ukraine Observes Another Independence Day as the War Rages On
item.description: On the second Independence Day since Russia’s full-scale invasion, the mood in Kyiv was subdued.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Daria Mitiuk
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times

item.title: What to Know About the Plane Crash Believed to Have Killed Prigozhin
item.description: The Wagner mercenary group leader, who staged a short-lived mutiny against Russia’s military leadership in June, was presumed dead after a jet went down northwest of Moscow on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

item.title: Jacobite Hero Bonnie Prince Charlie Gets a Fresh Face, Acne and All
item.description: The prince, Charles Edward Stuart, led a Jacobite uprising in the Scottish Highlands in 1745. A new recreation of his face seeks to humanize the man behind the legend.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil

item.title: Ex-Principal of Australian Girls School Sentenced to 15 Years for Abuse
item.description: Malka Leifer, extradited from Israel after a lengthy process, was found guilty in April of sexually abusing two students decades earlier.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Malka Leifer at a courtroom in Jerusalem in 2018.

item.title: A Russian Court Extends the Pretrial Detention of Journalist Evan Gershkovich
item.description: A Moscow court on Thursday extended the pretrial detention of the American reporter, who has denied the espionage charges he faces. The U.S. says he has been wrongfully detained.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova

item.title: Dissident Who Fled China by Jet Ski Said to Have Planned Escape for Years
item.description: Officials in South Korea aren’t saying who crossed 200 miles of ocean to reach its shores. But people who know Kwon Pyong say it wasn’t his first audacious move.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Korea Coast Guard, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: South Korea’s Coast Guard, which released this image, said it had detained a man who was found stranded with this vehicle off the country’s west coast last week. The front of the watercraft was blurred by the source.

item.title: Ukraine Observes Independence Day With Subdued Celebrations
item.description: The Ukrainian authorities said the national holiday, which comes exactly 18 months after Russia’s full-scale invasion, won’t include public celebrations amid concerns about Russian attacks.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times

item.title: Prigozhin, Wagner Leader, Believed to Be on Plane in Deadly Russia Crash
item.description: All 10 people on a jet linked to Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the mercenary group, were killed on Wednesday, Russian officials said.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Russian government on Wednesday shows first responders at the site of a plane crash near the village of Kuzhenkino, in Russia’s Tver region.

item.title: North Korea’s 2nd Satellite Launch Fails to Reach Orbit
item.description: The ​rocket failure was an embarrassment for the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, who badly needed a morale booster for his people.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A television in Seoul on Wednesday showed file footage of North Korea’s second rocket launch, which ended in failure.

item.title: Warren Hoge, Who Covered Wars and World Crises for The Times, Dies at 82
item.description: A correspondent and bureau chief, he wrote vividly from all corners of the globe before rising in newsroom leadership as foreign editor and assistant managing editor.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:credit: Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times
item.media:description: Warren Hoge in 1976, the year he was hired by The Times to be a reporter on the metropolitan desk, covering New York-area news.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Prigozhin Listed Aboard Crashed Plane
item.description: Also, a paralyzed woman regains her voice.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the head of the Wagner Private Military Company, leaving Rostov-on-Don, Russia, after his aborted mutiny in June of this year.

item.title: How Multiple Warnings About Killer Nurse Lucy Letby Were Missed
item.description: Since the trial of Lucy Letby, a nurse who murdered babies in her care, experts have warned of a culture of hostility toward whistle-blowers in Britain’s National Health Service.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: The Countess of Chester Hospital in Chester, England, where Lucy Letby worked. She was convicted of murdering premature infants.

item.title: Toto Cutugno, Singer Whose ‘L’Italiano’ Struck a Chord, Dies at 80
item.description: The nostalgic ballads and catchy pop songs he wrote paved the way for an international career. He sold more than 100 million albums worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Toto Cutugno in 1983, the year of his hugely popular song “L’Italiano.”

item.title: Atop an Underwater Hot Spring, an ‘Octopus Garden’ Thrives
item.description: The heat, a new study suggests, makes for an ideal breeding ground for these eight-legged animals.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller

item.title: In Photos: Greece’s Catastrophic Wildfires
item.description: Firefighters are struggling to quell deadly flames, part of a crisis of wildfires in the nation this summer. Here are photos from the latest blazes.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Firefighters near Mount Parnitha in Athens early on Thursday.

item.title: Greece Battles Its Most Widespread Wildfires on Record
item.description: Extreme heat has turned much of the country into a tinderbox. More than 350 fires have broken out in the past five days, the government said.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Firefighters in Chasia, on the outskirts of Athens, on Tuesday. Of the many fires, the fronts in the north and near Athens were considered the most dangerous.

item.title: Putin Again Blames West for Ukraine War In Speech to BRICS Summit
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin said Russia would assume chairmanship of the group made up of Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa next year and host a summit in the city of Kazan in October 2024.
item.dc:creator: Enjoli Liston and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia delivering remarks via video link, during a summit of BRICS nations in Johannesburg on Wednesday.

item.title: At Least 26 Die as Bridge Collapses While Under Construction in India
item.description: A rescue effort was underway as reports indicated that several additional workers were trapped under the wreckage.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Zoramthanga, via X, formerly known as Twitter
item.media:description: A photo shared on social media by Mizoram State, India, showed the damaged bridge.

item.title: China Works to Expand its Sway in Africa Amid Rivalry With the U.S.
item.description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, pitches his country as a leader of the developing world, rallying support for an alternative to the U.S.-dominated global order.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, the Chinese leader, with President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa in Pretoria on Tuesday.

item.title: In the Heart of the Australian Outback, Safeguarding a Sacred Land
item.description: On a road trip in central Australia, a visitor learns how Indigenous custodians and conservationists are working to protect an ancient land and its animal denizens.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Ham

item.title: Russia Says Ukrainian Drones Targeted Moscow for a Sixth Consecutive Day
item.description: Drone attacks in Russian territory have become more frequent as Ukraine wages a grueling counteroffensive.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Valeriya Safronova
item.media:description: Inspecting the damaged building in Moscow on Wednesday.

item.title: Canadian Officials Condemn Facebook for News Ban as Wildfires Burn
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said it was “inconceivable” that the platform had responded to a new licensing law by blocking news links, as the country confronts its worst wildfire season on record.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:description: Smoke from wildfires enveloped Kelowna, British Columbia, on Friday.

item.title: At BRICS Summit, Putin Tries to Rally Support
item.description: Leaders of Brazil, India, China and South Africa addressed other topics, but Russia’s president, unable to attend in person because he is wanted for war crimes, put the war in Ukraine at center stage in the meeting.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia addressed the BRICS summit remotely on Tuesday. Under indictment by the International Criminal Court, Mr. Putin faces arrest if he travels to South Africa.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: A Dangerous Rescue in Pakistan
item.description: Also, exploring street food in Fukuoka, Japan.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Six children and two adults were suspended for several hours inside a cable car and rescued by a military helicopter in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, Pakistan, on Tuesday.

item.title: As West Bank Shootings Rise, Israel’s Government Vows to Retaliate
item.description: An apparently unarmed Palestinian man and an Israeli teacher were among the recent victims. Israel’s government has pledged to strike at Palestinian assailants.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Israeli forces blocked a road after a father and son were shot in the West Bank town of Huwara on Saturday.

item.title: Canadian Wildfires Twice as Likely Because of Climate Change, Study Finds
item.description: Climate change has made hot, dry and windy conditions like those that fueled this year’s blazes at least twice as common as they would otherwise be.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Daryann Gauthier/Société de protection des forêt, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Wildfire smoke in northern Quebec last month.

item.title: A Saudi Rolex Sold in a U.S. Mall Could Get Bolsonaro Arrested
item.description: Brazil’s former president, Jair Bolsonaro, is the target of multiple criminal investigations. One includes a watch, gifted by the Saudis, sold in a Pennsylvania mall.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro, the former Brazilian president, denies wrongdoing in each of the investigations into him, saying the allegations are fabrications that amount to political persecution.

item.title: Ukraine’s Forces and Firepower Are Misallocated, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: American strategists say Ukraine’s troops are too spread out and need to concentrate along the counteroffensive’s main front in the south.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Julian E. Barnes, Helene Cooper and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian marines training in the Zaporizhzhia region before heading to the frontline. American officials say more Ukrainian forces should be near Zaporizhzhia and in the south of the country.

item.title: European Climate Czar Steps Down to Take Part in Dutch Elections
item.description: Frans Timmermans is stepping down at a crucial time for European climate laws to become the lead candidate for a left-wing coalition in the Dutch elections in November.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Frans Timmermans at a European Commission meeting in Brussels in March.

item.title: 18 People Killed in Greek Wildfire May Be Migrants
item.description: The authorities said the bodies were found near the border with Turkey, in an area that is a crossing point for thousands of migrants seeking to enter Europe.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: A wildfire burning a home in the village of Avantas, near Alexandroupolis, Greece, on Monday. Gale-force winds are fanning wildfires across the country.

item.title: How the Pakistan Cable Car Passengers Were All Rescued Safely
item.description: Eight people, including seven students heading to a nearby school, were saved after being stranded for hours hundreds of feet above a valley in a remote, mountainous region of Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Zia ur-Rehman and Salman Masood
item.media:description: As a helicopter attempts to bring a rescuer closer, the local mayor said, “Wind from the rotor would jolt and unsettle the chairlift, causing the children to cry out in fear.”
